etymology.description: 释(phonetic loan for Śākya) + 迦(transliteration element) = “Śākya”; by resemblance → sugar apple.
etymology.interpretation: Borrowed from the Buddhist name Shakya; the fruit’s knobby surface recalls the Buddha’s curled hair, so the name was extended to this fruit. Often also called 番荔枝 in Mandarin.
etymology.simplification: 釋 was simplified to 释 via the official character simplification list to reduce strokes; 迦 stayed unchanged.

parts.english: used in transliterations; Sanskrit “ka/ga” sound; element in Buddhist names; surname

examples.chinese: 台湾盛产释迦(臺灣盛產釋迦)，味道香甜(味道香甜)。
examples.english: Taiwan produces sugar apples in abundance, and they taste sweet and fragrant.

examples.chinese: 这种水果也叫番荔枝(這種水果也叫番荔枝)。
examples.pinyin: Zhè zhǒng shuǐguǒ yě jiào fān lìzhī.
examples.english: This fruit is also called sugar apple (custard apple).

examples.chinese: 释迦成熟时(釋迦成熟時)，果皮会裂开(果皮會裂開)。
examples.pinyin: Shìjiā chéngshú shí, guǒpí huì lièkāi.
examples.english: When sugar apples ripen, the skin cracks open.
